questions.text: Double decidua is seen during
questions.solution:
USG Signs

1.Intradecidual sign: Due to formation of G sac and interstitial implantation.

Seen during 4 weeks of period of gestation

2.Double bleb sign: Due to formation of yolk sac and amniotic sac.Seen at 5 weeks of Period of gestation

3.Double decidual sac sign: Two rings are seen around the G.sac

Outer ring: Decidua parietalis

Inner ring: Decidua capsularis

Double bleb sign and double decidual signs are absent in ectopic pregnancy and are diagnostic of intrauterine pregnancy

questions.text: Female with 41week gestation confirmed by radiological investigation, very sure of her LMP, no uterine contractions, no effacement and no dilatation. What should not be done
questions.solution:
This is a case of post term pregnancy and MgSO4 has no role here.

MgSO4

  • MgSO4 is the drug of choice for prevention and management of convulsions.
  • MgSO4 is also used as a neuroprotective agent for

Mechanism of action:

  • It decreases the acetylcholine release from the nerve endings and decreases the sensitivity of motor end plate to Ach.
  • Blocks the calcium channel and decreases intracranial

Regimens for MgSO4:

Pritchard Regimen

Total Loading Dose =14 gm

4 gm of 20% MgSO4 slow IV

Followed by 10gm of 50% MgSO4- 5gm in each buttock IM

Maintenance dose: 5gm of 50% MGSO$ IM in alternate buttocks every 4 hours

Zuspan Regimen

4 gm 20% MgSO4 IV over 5-10 min

followed by 1gm/hr MgSO4 IV infusion for 24 hours

Therapeutic range - 4 to 7 mEq/L

  • There is a narrow range at which therapeutic effect and toxic effects of Magnesium occurs, therefore monitoring for magnesium toxicity is very difficult.

Options A,B,C are used for cervical ripening and induction of labour which is necessary in this patient with postterm pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is correct about acute fatty liver of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
• Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP) is a rare condition that typically occurs in the third trimester of pregnancy.
  • It is more common in the third trimester but can also occur in the second trimester.
  • It is associated with disorders of fatty acid transport and oxidation, often related to a deficiency of the LCHAD enzyme.
  • AFLP is a serious condition that requires prompt recognition and intervention as it can lead to acute liver failure.
  • It is not specifically associated with the gender of the fetus (Option C ruled out) or a particular level of uric acid (Option D ruled out).
  • The incidence is estimated to be around 1 in 7,000 to 1 in 15,000 pregnancies rather than 1 in 1000 (Option A ruled out).

Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy (AFLP) / Acute Yellow Atrophy of the Liver:

Aetiology:

  • Rare condition occurring in the third trimester (mean gestational age of 37.5 weeks).
  • Most common cause of acute liver failure during pregnancy.

Associated Risk Factors:

  • Disorders of fatty acid transport and oxidation, particularly deficiency of LCHAD enzyme (long-chain hydroxyl acetyl coenzyme A dehydrogenase).
  • Increased risk in first pregnancies, male fetuses, preeclampsia, maternal obesity, and multiple pregnancies.

Histology:

  • Liver appears yellow, soft, and greasy.
  • Swollen hepatocytes with central nuclei and cytoplasm filled with microvesicular fat.
  • Periportal sparing acute yellow atrophy.
  • Minimal hepatocellular pathology.

Clinical Features:

  • Typically presents in the third trimester (around 37 weeks) with nonspecific symptoms like nausea, vomiting, anorexia, vague abdominal discomfort, and malaise.
  • Persistent vomiting may be a prominent symptom.
  • AFP should be suspected in any woman with new-onset nausea and malaise in the third trimester.
  • Progresses to jaundice over about one week.
  • In 50% of cases, features of preeclampsia such as hypertension, proteinuria, and edema are present.
  • Severe cases may lead to endothelial cell activation, hemoconcentration, hepatorenal syndrome, ascites, and sometimes pulmonary edema.
  • Maternal leukocytosis and thrombocytopenia may occur.

Investigations:

  • Abnormal liver function tests:
    • Rise in serum bilirubin (usually less than 10 mg/dL).
    • Increased SGOT and SGPT (less than 1000 IU/L).
    • Moderately increased alkaline phosphatase.
    • Prothrombin time may be increased.
    • Prolonged clotting time.
  • Severe cases may exhibit disseminated coagulation failure.
  • Abnormal renal function tests, including elevated serum creatinine and uric acid levels.
  • Other abnormalities: Hypoglycemia, decreased platelet count, and low fibrinogen levels.

Management:

  • Rapid delivery is essential.
  • Mode of delivery: Induction of labor followed by vaginal delivery.
  • Cesarean section is avoided if possible due to coagulopathy but is still common in practice.

Complications:

  • Maternal mortality ranges from 10% to 75%.
  • Hepatic dysfunction typically resolves postpartum.
  • Postpartum complications may include transient diabetes insipidus and acute pancreatitis.

Fetal Prognosis:

  • Generally poor.
  • Surviving fetuses may develop a Reye-like syndrome with hepatic encephalopathy and severe hypoglycemia due to a defect in beta-fatty acid oxidation.

questions.text: MgSO4 have no role in prevention of?
questions.solution:
Uses of MgSO4:

Magnesium sulfate infusions have been a common practice on obstetrical floors for more than 60 years. It's a well-studied drug, so doctors know very well how it affects moms and babies. Here is how it is used:

  • In Preterm Labor: To Allow Time For Steroids

Magnesium sulfate is a tocolytic that has been used to slow or stop premature labor.

Doctors may treat preterm labor with 48 hours of magnesium sulfate, hoping to buy enough time to complete a course of steroids to help the baby's lungs develop.

  • In Preeclampsia: To Prevent Seizures

Preeclampsia is a common complication of pregnancy that causes high blood pressure and protein in the urine. If not treated, preeclampsia can develop into eclampsia, a seizure disorder.

The only cure for preeclampsia and eclampsia is delivery of the baby, but magnesium sulfate can help prevent seizures in women with severe preeclampsia.

  • In Preterm Babies: To Protect Newborn Brains

Premature babies, especially those who are born before about 32 weeks gestation, have immature brains at birth. As they grow, they are at risk for cerebral palsy, a disorder that affects movement and intelligence.

Short-term (24 hours or less) infusions of magnesium sulfate have been shown to help protect the baby's brain by reducing the incidence of cerebral palsy.

questions.text: Overt gestational diabetes is defined as blood glucose more than
questions.solution:
Overt diabetes: Diabetic female has conceived.(Deranged blood glucose levels prior to 20 weeks POG)

Pregestational diabetes-from day 1 blood glucose is increased a Formation of free radicals that can lead to congenital malformations in fetus.

Can be seen in T1, T2, T3 and doesn't resolve after delivery

Gestational diabetes: Previously normoglycemic female- during pregnancy due to insulin resistance becomes diabetic. Seen after 24-28 weeks, i.e in T2 and T3(T3>T2) and not in T1. Hence doesn't lead to congenital malformations in fetus and Resolves after delivery.

AMERICAN DIABETES ASSOCIATION- For Overt Diabetes:

FBS >/=126mg% or

RBS >/=200mg% or 2hr PP>/=200mg%

HbA1C >/=6.5

In India we follow DIPSI CRITERIA in all pregnant females:

  • 1stantenatal visit:Give 75 gms of oral glucose mixed in 300 ml of water, finish it in 10-15 mins.
  • Fasting not needed
  • After 2 hours(also called 2 hrs OGTT): Check the blood glucose levels.
    • If blood glucose >140mg%:Gestational diabetes
    • If blood glucose >200mg%:Overt diabetes.

questions.text: In 34 weeks gestation the weight of baby was 3 Kg. The child showing following features may indicate which associated condition?
questions.solution:
The figure shows the baby with macrosomia suggestive of Gestational Diabetes in mother

Congenital Malformations in Infants of Diabetic Mothers

Congenital malformation of fetus occurs in overt diabetic not in gestational diabetes

  • Cardiovascular: Cardiovascular abnormalities are the most common abnormalities in infants of diabetic
    • Ventricular septal defect and atrial septal defect
    • Transposition of the Great Vessels (TGV)-Most specific CVS-anomaly
    • Hypoplastic left ventricle
    • HOCM

Note: VSD is the most common cardiac anomaly and TGV is the most specific cardiac anomaly in infants of diabetic mothers. M/C finding in infants of diabetic mothers: HOCM.

  • Central Nervous System
    • Anencephaly and spina bifida
    • Encephalocele
    • Meningomyelocele and holoprosencephaly
    • Microcephaly

Skeletal

Caudal regression syndrome (sacral agenesis)-It is the most specific anomaly seen in babies of diabetic mother.

Neontal complicatios of Diabetes

  1. Hypoglycemia
  2. Hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia, hypokalemia
  3. Hyperbilirubinemia and polycythemia: Hyperviscosity syndrome
  4. Respiratory Distress Syndrome
  5. HOCM-reversible
  6. In diabetic females: Neonates do not have anemia and mental retardation
  7. M/C fetal complication:macrosomiaa Shoulder dystocia, prolonged labour

questions.text: Vulvar atrophy and itching are treated by
questions.solution:
Estrogen therapy and dehydroepiandrosterone(DHEA) are the only hormone therapies for vaginal atrophy.

Topical vaginal estrogen treats symptoms of vaginal atrophy without increasing levels of estrogen levels in your bloodstream. It’s available in a cream, a vaginal pill or a ring.

  • Vaginal estrogen cream: You put this cream into your vagina using an applicator. Most people need the cream daily for several weeks, but then 2-3 times per week.
  • Vaginal ring: A vaginal ring is a thin, flexible ring your healthcare provider places into your vagina. The ring releases a low dose of estrogen over the course of three months. Then your provider removes and replaces the ring.
  • Vaginal tablet: You place a small tablet into your vagina using an applicator. Like other estrogen treatments, you start out using it daily before tapering off to 2-3 times per week.

questions.text: 30-year-old woman with complaint of dysmenorrhoea, dyspareunia with chronic pelvic pain undergoes hysterectomy. From the cut section hysterectomy specimen below identify the condition.
questions.solution:
This is a case of Adenomyosis

  • Age group : Elderly patients > 40 years
  • Parity : Multiparous
  • Symptoms : Most common symptom: Menorrhagia

2nd most common symptom: Dysmenorrhea

Presenting feature: Menorrhagia and Dysmenorrhea

On per vaginal examination: Symmetrical enlargement of uterus(not more than 12-14 weeks of pregnancy)Q, mobility not restricted, no associated adnexal pathology.

Halban's sign - tender, softened uterus on premenstrual bimanual examination.

Fig. Gross specimen of Adenomyosis

Diagnosis

  • It is mainly
  • MRI(Junctional zone thickness >12 mm) is IOC
  • Gold standard-histopathological examination

Fig. Venetian blind appearance of Adenomyosis on MRI

Management

  • TOC-Surgery(total hysterectomy)Q in most of the patient, as most of the patients are elderly.
  • In younger women-localized excision can be tried or Levonorgestrel containing

IUCDs can also be tried.

questions.text: Premature ejaculation is seen in which phase?
questions.solution:
Premature ejaculation is a disorder of the orgasm phase.

Following are the phases of sexual response cycle and the disorders associated:


Premature ejaculation describes the phenomenon which occurs when ejaculation happens sooner than a man or his partner would like during sexual activity. It is considered the most common sexual disorder in the male population.

Nuchal translucency in USG can be detected at how many weeks of gestation?
questions.solution:
Nuchal translucency: Sonographic appearance of fluid filled area(black) below the skin below neck region on USG

It is best measured 11 weeks to 13weeks=6days(CRL:45-84mm).

If nuchal translucency is >3mm à problems in the fetus

  1. Trisomy(MC): Trisomy 21>18>13.
  2. Turner syndrome
  3. Cardiac defects in the fetus.

When nuchal translucency is abnormal -> Karyotyping

If karyotyping is normal -> Echocardiograph

Chorionic villi sampling: 11-13 weeks

Amniocentesis: 15-20 weeks

Cordocentesis: >18 weeks

questions.text: A female patient presented with recurrent urinary tract infections. Imaging shows the following picture. What can be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The cobra head sign in the image is suggestive of ureterocele. Ureterocele causes stasis of the urine which leads to recurrent UTI.

URETEROCELE

It is unknown exactly why ureteroceles form, but it is thought to be due to an abnormality of the formation of the ureter tube as it inserts into the bladder. Ureteroceles occur in about one of every 1000 births and are more common in a duplex kidney, which is a kidney with two ureters that drain into the bladder.

questions.text: The major contribution of the amniotic fluid after 20 weeks of gestation is
questions.solution:
Source of Amniotic Fluid:

  • Main Source:
    • Fetal urine.
  • Second Most Important Source (2nd Half of Pregnancy):
  • Upto 12 Weeks:
    • Transudate from maternal plasma.
  • 12-20 Weeks:
    • Fetal skin.
  • After >20 Weeks:
    • Fetal urine becomes the primary source.

Drainage Mechanism:

  • Swallowing:
    • Most important drainage method.
  • Initiation:
    • Begins by 10-12 weeks, followed by intramembranous transfer.

Other Contributors to Amniotic Fluid:

  • Early Pregnancy:
    • Ultrafiltrate of maternal plasma.
  • Beginning of Second Trimester:
    • Extracellular fluid diffusion through fetal skin.
  • After 20 Weeks:
    • Cornification of fetal skin prevents diffusion, and amniotic fluid is mainly composed of fetal urine.

Minor Contributors:

  • Pulmonary fluid.
  • Fluid filtering through the placenta.

Fluid Replacement:

  • The water in the amniotic fluid is completely changed and replaced every 3 hours.

questions.text: In low ovarian reserve, anti mullerian hormone level will be:
questions.solution:
Serum antimüllerian Hormone (AMH): Levels of serum AMH is a good predictor of ovarian stimulation response. Its level also comes with the direct proportion of antral follicle count. Levels of AMH(1ng/mL) declines with age and with poor ovarian reserve. Levels of AMH can be measured any time in the menstrual cycle.

AMH: AMH is produced by the granulosa cells of the preantral small follicles. Serum levels of estradiol and inhibin B depend on pituitary FSH feedback mechanism. Level of AMH is not dependent on feedback mechanism. This is one of the reasons for which AMH is being considered as a better predictor of ovarian reserve compared to estradiol and inhibin B. Levels of AMH can be measured at anytime in the menstrual cycle. It therefore understood that AMH is qualitative whereas Antral Follicle Count(AFC) is a quantitative marker of ovarian reserve.

questions.text: 45 years female with 6 months menorrhagia. USG showing 2cm submucosal fibroid. Definitive treatment will be?
questions.solution:
Management of Fibroids

Indications for Operating an Asymptomatic Fibroid :

  • Fibroids larger than 12-14 weeks
  • Rapidly growing
  • Subserous and pedunculated fibroid prone to
  • If it is likely to complicate a future pregnancy
  • If there is doubt about its nature
  • Unexplained infertility and unexplained recurrent -DuttaGynae 4th/ed p 264
  • Uncertain diagnosis:If patient is symptomatic decide whether you give medical treatment or surgical treatment.

Indications of Medical Management

  • To treat anemia and recover hemoglobin levels before
  • To reduce the size of large fibroid and facilitate
  • Treatment of women approaching menopause to avoid
  • In women with medical contraindication to surgery or those who are postponing surgery.
  • For preservation of fertility in women with large myomas before conservative surgery like myomectomy.

Indications of Surgical Management

Fibroids causing any symptoms like

  • Menorrhagiaor pressure symptomslike urinary retention(by a cervical or broad ligament fibroid) or chronic pelvic pain withsevere dysmenorrhea, acute pelvic pain as in torsion of a pedunculated fibroid or prolapsing submucosal fibroid
  • Unexplained infertility
  • Recurrent abortions due to submucous fibroid
  • Rapidly growing

questions.solution: Chicken pox vaccine being a live vaccine is contraindicated in pregnancy.
